title: NC (complexity)
summary: In computational complexity theory, the class NC (for "Nick's Class") is the set of decision problems decidable in polylogarithmic time on a parallel computer with a polynomial number of processors.  In other words, a problem with input size n is in NC if there exist constants c and k such that it can be solved in time O(logcÂ n) using O(nk) parallel processors. Stephen Cook[1][2] coined the name "Nick's class" after Nick Pippenger, who had done extensive research[3] on circuits with polylogarithmic depth and polynomial size.[4]
